body.p: warning dialogdialogwarningSend a warn: message to the Dialog class, with a string specifying the message.

When the user clicks OK, the message returns the value nil. Backslash characters in the string are converted to carriage returns by the withCRs message. warn | returnVal | returnVal := Dialog warn: 'The memory named\''FirstKiss''\was not found.\' withCRs. "Update the text field in the main window." self returnedValue value: returnVal printString.

li.p: Send a confirm: message to the Dialog class. The argument is the question to be asked. Dialog confirm: 'Really erase all memories\of adolescent period?\' withCRs.

To specify a different default answer, send a confirm:initialAnswer: message to Dialog instead, with the as either true or false. Dialog confirm: 'Really erase all memories\of adolescent period?' withCRs initialAnswer: false

To adopt the look of a master window, send a confirm:initialAnswer:for: message, with the master window as the third argument: returnVal := Dialog confirm: 'Really erase all memories\of adolescent period?' withCRs initialAnswer: false for: ScheduledControllers activeController view.

body.p: multiple-choice dialogdialogmultiple choiceSend a choose:labels:values:default: message to the Dialog class. The choose: argument is the question, the labels: argument is an array of Strings for the button labels, the values: argument is an array of Symbols to return values for each buttons, and the default: argument is the Symbol for the default answer. Dialog choose: 'Which memory would you like to review first?' labels: #( 'Swimming the Channel' 'Triumph at the Coliseum' 'Love & War #47') values: #(#swim #triumph #love47) default: #triumph

To adopt the look of a master window, send a choose:labels:values:default:for: message instead, with the master window as the for: argument. returnVal := Dialog choose: 'Which memory would you like to review first?' labels: #( 'Swimming the Channel' 'Triumph at the Coliseum' 'Love & War #47') values: #(#swim #triumph #love47) default: #triumph for: ScheduledControllers activeController view.

dialogtext responsetext-response dialogSend a request:initialAnswer: message to Dialog, with a prompt string and a default answer string. Dialog request: 'Find all memories associated with...' initialAnswer: 'friend'
If there is no default answer, you can use the shorter request:, and provide the question string only.

dialogcancel actionA text prompter, by default, returns an empty string when the user clicks Cancel. To provide a specific action on cancel, use the request:initialAnswer:cancel: message. The argument for cancel: is a block that returns a value or initiates some further action. getText | returnVal | returnVal := Dialog request: 'Find all memories associated with...' initialAnswer: 'friend' onCancel: [self defaultRuminationTopic].

file dialogdialogfile prompterSend a requestFileName:default: message to Dialog, with a prompter string and the name of the default file as a string. Dialog requestFileName: 'Open memory file named...' default: 'hero01.mem'
If a default file name isn’t needed, use the shorter requestFileName: message.

topic.title: Prompt with a list of items

body.p: dialoglist optionsTo display a dialog with a list of commands or data values, send a choose:fromList:values:lines:cancel: message to Dialog. The choose: argument contains the prompt string; the fromList: argument contains a collection of strings (command names or value descriptions); the values: argument, a collection of values associated with the fromList: items; lines: contains the maximum number of list items to display; and cancel: passes a block containing the cancel action.

Each item in the list is associated with a value which can insert the selected value in a value holder or trigger an action. | files response | files := Filename defaultDirectory directoryContents reject: [ :name | name asFilename isDirectory]. response := Dialog choose: 'Edit which file?' fromList: files values: files lines: 8 cancel: [^nil]. response asFilename edit.

To Supply extra buttons to the list prompter, send a choose:fromList:values:buttons:values:lines:cancel: message instead, where the buttons: argument is a collection of strings to be used as button labels and the values: argument is a collection of values to associate with the button labels. response := Dialog choose: 'Edit which file?' fromList: files values: files buttons: #('Count Files') values: #(#count) lines: 12 cancel: [^nil].

topic.title: Link a dialog to a master window

body.p: GUI developmentlink dialog to windowdialoglink to windowTo open dialogs that mimic the colors and UI Look of a master window, use the instance opening protocol including a for: argument ( e.g., warn:for:) to specify the UI Look.

To change the colors used, send a useColorOveridesFromParent: true message to SimpleDialog.
Send a useColorOveridesFromParent: true message to the SimpleDialog class. Subsequently opened dialogs will adopt the colors of their master window.
Send a warn:for: message to the Dialog class. The first argument is the message string, and the second argument is the master window. | masterWindow | SimpleDialog useColorOveridesFromParent: true. masterWindow := ScheduledWindow new. masterWindow background: ColorValue yellow. masterWindow open. Dialog warn: 'This dialog has a yellow background, too.' for: masterWindow. masterWindow sensor eventQuit: nil.
To reset the SimpleDialog class to its default behavior, send it the useColorOveridesFromParent: false message with the argument .

dialogcustomCreate a subclass of SimpleDialog, reusing its protocol for #accept or #cancel. In the method that is to open the dialog, send an openDialogInterface: message to the application model. The argument is the dialog’s interface specification. openDialogCanvas | returnVal | returnVal := self openDialogInterface: #memoryZonesDialog. "Update the text field in the main window." self returnedValue value: returnVal printString.
